docs.lead_paragraph: An expensive bidding war for a blood test maker, Biosite, may grow even pricier. On Thursday, Inverness Medical Innovations made a $1.6 billion tender offer, topping an earlier $1.55 billion offer from Beckman Coulter. The bid by Inverness, which already owns 4.9 percent of Biosite, values Biosite at about $90 a share. Beckman Coulter's offer was valued at about $85 a share.

headline.main: Inverness Injects Itself into Biosite Fight

docs.lead_paragraph: Since when did having a child become a feminist imperative?

headline.seo: Babies - Pregnancy - Feminism - Baby Lust - Peggy Orenstein

docs.snippet: Since when did having a child become a feminist imperative?

docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Showtime) THE TUDORS Henry VIII’s contributions to history include the Church of England, sanctioned divorce and multiple beheadings. A new series further sexes up the story of this English king by taking a look at the young Henry (Jonathan Rhys Meyers, left) as he begins to form the legacy for which he would be known. In the first episode Henry prepares for war with France, and a lady-in-waiting becomes pregnant.

docs.lead_paragraph: Here is a smattering of things I did during the six-year quest to conceive my daughter: interrupt love-making to squirt raw egg whites into myself with a turkey baster (it's reputed to abet the feminine fluid that speeds sperm to egg); substitute two teaspoons of Robitussin for my morning coffee (its main ingredient thins and loosens mucous in the lungs, and although there is no actual proof, it's thought to work similar juju farther south); down ovulation-stimulating pills that triggered fits of rage; inject myself with the urine of postmenopausal Italian nuns (the original source of some fertility drugs, though it's hard to imagine how the goods are gathered); chug unidentifiable herbal potions that tasted like garden mulch; squander what would have been the college fund on long-shot in-vitro-fertilization treatments; imperil my marriage.
